Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Assessing the Impacts of Sea Level Rise on Coastal Semi-Aquatic Snake Distributions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Global-mean sea level is projected to rise by roughly one meter over the next 85 years. These changes are expected to detrimentally impact mangrove and coastal wetland habitats that contain high levels of species diversity. Of particular concern is Singapore that on average lies only 15 m above sea level and has lost much of its native mangrove habitat. Many semi-aquatic snake species of the family Homalopsidae rely on this imperiled habitat and changes in sea-level could cause species extirpations. Particularly concerning is the fact that many of these poorly understood snakes are found nowhere else and new species are described regularly. As regulating predators in coastal ecosystems, snake losses could result in unnatural levels of some prey species, such as fish and crustaceans, and the disappearance of others - directly impacting fisheries and other economically important coastal recreational activities. In this study, semi-aquatic snakes will be sampled across Singapore to gather information on distribution and abundance necessary for predicting species responses to sea level rise. This research is in collaboration with Dr. David Bickford at the National University of Singapore, a world-renowned expert in evolutionary ecology and conservation.

Occupancy analysis will be used to model species occupancy, detectability, and habitat associations for semi-aquatic snake species. Up to 30 coastal sites representing a gradient from pristine (i.e. National Parks) to sites heavily influenced by urban development will be sampled. Surveys will be conducted at night in mangroves, intertidal creeks and mud flats at low tides when snakes are most active. Habitat and landscape variables such as salinity, land cover, urban land use, and vegetation cover will be included as covariates, to assess relationships between natural and anthropogenic factors and species occupancy and diversity. Predicted distribution maps for each species will be created using the results from occupancy modeling. Potentially inundated areas will be mapped using multiple probabilistic sea level rise scenarios for estimating impacts on costal habitat. These maps will then be overlaid to estimate impacts on species persistence. This study is the first of its kind investigating occupancy parameters in Asian snakes and responses of snakes to projected sea-level rise. This award is funded in collaboration with the National University of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Homalopsidae is a rare family of aquatic snakes with unique specializations adapted to coastal wetland environments. These specializations allow homalopsids to play an important predatory role within harsh, complex coastal ecosystems. However, as rare specialists, these snakes are predicted to be more vulnerable to extinction than other species. Loss of important predators in coastal ecosystems has been demonstrated to produce devastating consequences to species richness, abundance and ecosystem function in cornerstone studies.

The main objective of this study was to assess homalopsid snake distribution and abundance in Singapore to lay a foundation for future population and distribution monitoring and predict species responses to global change, such as sea level rise. We also sought to identify significant landscape and wetland variables that influence species occupancy (distribution) and detection (abundance) probability estimates. To do this, we systematically sampled a total of twenty two coastal sites across Singapore at night for snakes. We also collected data such as prey abundance (eg. fish, crabs) and habitat structure (lobster mounds, mudskipper holes, tidal creeks and pools), in addition to a post hoc landscape analysis, to assess the composition of habitat types at each site. This information allowed us to model how likely any of these variables significantly influenced where a species is found and how abundant it is.

We found that most snake species using coastal habitats are estimated to be of low abundance and are restricted to small distributions in Singapore. These restricted distributions are likely a product of many species being habitat or dietary specialists which are known to show difficulty adapting to degraded, urbanized, and fragmented landscapes.  For example, we found snake species richness, or the number of snake species within a habitat, decreased closer to urbanization. However, one species of homalopsid was common and widely distributed in Singapore, including highly urbanized habitats. Although it appears to be a habitat generalist, it is more abundant in habitats with more fish. We also found mangrove habitats had higher species richness estimates than tidal creeks, mud flats, canals, beaches and rocky shoreline. Additionally, three species thought to be mangrove specialists were significantly more abundant in areas with more mangroves. Information on the relationship between tide height and species detectability was also collected. Finally, novel reptile and amphibian natural history and distribution information was acquired as a side product of our study.

This study is the first to estimate detection and occupancy parameters for a Southeast Asian snake community within an occupancy modeling and species richness framework. This study significantly increases our understanding of rare coastal snake communities, which are currently threatened and poorly understood. Our results provide evidence that sea-level rise, urbanization, and mangrove destruction may threaten rare, specialist species, particularly obligate mangroves specialists. It also identifies variables important to the presence or absence of some species, and highlights the significance of maintaining existing preserves of mangrove habitat within Singapore that are species rich. Finally, we plan to further investigate how variations in predicted sea level rise may influence homalopsid snake distributions in Southeast Asia, using results from this study.
